I would rather do practical tasks than write long essays.

I can imagine myself in work like IT, engineering, finance or science.
In group tasks or projects, I often end up taking the lead.
I enjoy organising people and making sure things get done.

I like the idea of a job with a clear routine and predictable tasks.
I feel calmer when I know exactly what is expected of me each day.
I can imagine myself in reliable support roles (for example admin, receptionist, back-office).
I would rather have a safe, steady income than take big risks for a more exciting job.
It is hard for me to concentrate in noisy, busy places like open classrooms or malls.

I feel energised in lively environments where there is a lot happening.
I like schools or workplaces that have a buzz and constant interaction.

I get stressed when teachers or leaders change plans at the last minute.
I prefer flexible days where I can decide the order in which I do tasks.
Very strict, rule-heavy environments make me feel trapped.
I enjoy working in teams and bouncing ideas off other people.
I prefer working alone where I can go at my own pace.
Group projects usually energise me rather than drain me.

Col4: 1 = Not at all true of me

Col1: Teen Future Work & Study Direction Screener (Neural Imprint based)

This assessment is for teenagers who want to understand what kind of future work and study paths might fit them best. It looks at your interests, the type of environments you function well in, how you like to learn, and some patterns that might help or hinder your future choices.

It uses the 16 Neural Imprint Patterns as a background lens, but it is NOT a formal psychometric career test and does NOT replace professional career counselling or psychological assessment. The results are designed for self-reflection, coaching and guided conversations with parents, mentors, teachers or counsellors.

How to answer:
• Think about how you usually are over the last 6–12 months.
• Answer honestly, not how you think you should be.
• Use the scale 1–4:
   1 = Not at all true of me
   2 = A little true of me
   3 = Often true of me
   4 = Completely true of me
Teen Future Work & Study Direction – Neural Imprint Summary

This profile gives an overview of your future work and study direction based on your interests, preferred environments, learning style and key Neural Imprint patterns. It is meant to support conversation and planning, not to put you in a box or make final decisions for you.
Key areas to look at with your coach or mentor:
- Your strongest interest areas (for example people, practical, creative, systems, leadership, stability).
- The kind of work and study environments where you are most likely to function well.
- How you learn best (hands-on, theory, social learning, self-discipline needs).
- Risk and support patterns in your Neural Imprints that could affect your future path.
